Comment: The votes to be counted aren't distributed evenly. There are a _lot_ more small counties than large counties, and small counties' votes are easier and faster to count.  As an example: the smallest county in Texas (Loving County) has a population of 94. The largest, Harris County, has a population of 4,835,125. They certainly don't have 50,000 times as many people _counting_ votes in Harris county, so the rate is necessarily slower. (see https://www.texas-demographics.com/counties_by_population.)

Comment: Yeah--other policies that lead to slow vote counting are:  * accepting mail-in ballots after the election as long as they're post-marked by election day--a big issue in Alaska where postal service from rural places to the place where votes are counted can be very slow, and to a lesser extent across a lot of the west where voting by mail is very popular because polling places can be a long way away  * signature verification--tends to slow down the process considerably  * [allowing ballots to be cured](https://www.npr.org/2022/09/27/1125179062/voting-explainer-in-many-states-theres-a-process-to-fix-an-error-with-your-ballo)--some states have a process to allow voters to fix issues with their ballot (like they forgot to sign the envelope) and usually they have until several days after the election to do this
